channel.title: Radio National Breakfast - Breakfast Wrap
channel.description: Filtered feed containing only Breakfast Wrap episodes from Radio National Breakfast
channel.itunes:author: ABC Radio National

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam, 50 years on
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Neo-Nazi protest outside state parliament shocks Sydney
item.description:
NSW Police and the state government are reviewing how neo-Nazis were able to legally rally outside state parliament in Sydney on the weekend.

We'll hear from the state's police minister as the Premier says he's planning to toughen up the state's laws. 

Then, the Liberal party  could be just days away from deciding its future climate policy and whether it will commit to net-zero by 2050.

And we'll hear about the long career of late talk radio pioneer John Laws, who has died at the age of 90. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Pacific pressure on Australia's COP30 delegation
item.description:
Pressure is mounting on the Australian delegation to COP30 to resolve an impasse with Türkiye over hosting rights for the next global climate talks in 2026.

But Australia's bid remains in doubt, as global leaders begin to question why Prime Minister Anthony Albanese won't be making the trip across the Pacific to personally vouch for Australia's case.

Then, it's been six months since the Coalition lost a landslide election to Labor.

So has the Liberal Party learnt the lessons it promised to follow after the election, or is it doomed to keep repeating history?

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What's behind SA's harmful algal bloom?
item.description:
As South Australian beaches prepare for their first summer with the devastating algal bloom, scientists believe they may have identified a little-known algal species behind the event.

The breakthrough research, which is undergoing academic peer review, has found that Karenia Cristata is the dominant species in this major bloom event.

Then, questions about the Liberal party's leadership and the Coalition's future intensified this week as the Liberal party continues to review its energy policy.

And as Australia's social media ban for children under-16 fast approaches, how much do you know about the platforms on the ban list, like Reddit and Kick? 

We'll also head to the US where the Supreme Court has begun hearing a landmark case on the legality of Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs.

And we'll turn to a  Democrat strategist for the washup of the New York City Mayoral race. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: America's most powerful modern vice president
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Can the Liberals afford to water down net-zero?
item.description:
The Opposition Leader Sussan Ley has been facing internal tensions for months and now there are questions over how she'll handle splitting views within the party on whether to keep a commitment to net zero emissions by 2050. 

The Nationals' decided to formally abandon the target ahead of today's Coalition party room meeting. So you'll hear from a Coalition frontbencher ahead of the meeting.

Then, major news overseas, the former chief lawyer for the Israeli military is in police custody after admitting she leaked a damaging video appearing to show soldiers abusing a Palestinian man in jail.

We'll also cross to France, where prosecutors in Paris say the daring jewellery heist at the Louvre was carried out by petty criminals, not organised professionals.

And you'll meet the man hoping to beat his father's sailing record - solo circumnavigating the globe.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Liberals under pressure after Nationals dump net zero
item.description:
The National Party has scrapped its commitment to reach net zero emissions by 2050, but says it still wants to reduce emissions.

It comes as its partner in the Coalition— the Liberal Party —  continues its review into energy policy. 

Then, US President Donald Trump says he has ordered the Pentagon to prepare for potential military action in Nigeria if it fails to crack down on the killing of Christians.

Back home, a landmark new report has revealed around 65,000 First Nations' households which have prepaid supply arrangements are being disconnected up to 59 times per year.

And the Australian music industry has launched a campaign to localise our streaming algorithms and highlight homegrown talent. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: A royal eviction: Prince Andrew loses titles
item.description:
King Charles will strip brother Prince Andrew of his remaining royal titles and evict him from his royal residence, after weeks of pressure to act over Andrew's relationship with sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

Then, we turn to the applause and tears in Victoria's parliament as Victoria becomes the first state in Australia to legislate a treaty with Aboriginal people following a late-night vote. 

And US President Donald Trump and his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping have taken steps to de-escalate their trade war following a meeting at an international airport in South Korea yesterday. We'll get reaction from the federal government and wrap the week in politics with our friday political panel. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Labor's race to pass environmental reforms
item.description:
The federal government's long-awaited overhaul of environmental approvals will be introduced to parliament today.

But passage for the bills will be treacherous, with the Coalition calling it a "handbrake on investment"  and the Greens arguing it "weakens environmental protection".

Then, we get the details on reports of paramilitary forces committing mass killings and other atrocities in the Sudanese city of el-Fasher.

And we'll go inside an unprecedented corporate dumping. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Israel launches fresh strikes on Gaza
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What's at stake for the Trump-Xi meeting?
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Environment reforms in focus as parliament returns
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Russia responds to new US sanctions
item.description: Agenda-setting news coverage, breaking news and stories impacting the lives of all Australians.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: ICJ says Israel must allow UN aid into Gaza
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: What the critical minerals deal means for Australia
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Unpacking Albanese's meeting with Trump
item.description: Coverage and analysis of national and international events.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Joyce contemplates life after Nationals
item.description:
Nationals MP Barnaby Joyce has confirmed he won't recontest the seat of New England at the next federal election.

Today, we hear from Mr Joyce amid fevered speculation that he is contemplating joining One Nation.

We also speak with a former Ukrainian prime minister as Australia's Prime Minister, Anthony Albanese, prepares to meet with US President Donald Trump.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Lord Mayor warns against Liberal 'lecturing'
item.description:
The Lord Mayor of Melbourne has warned the federal Liberal party about lecturing his state, after Opposition leader Sussan Ley spent the week in Melbourne criticising the city's crime rates. 

Today we hear from Nicholas Reece and opposition Senator Jane Hume. 

Then, cryptocurrency ATMs could be banned in Australia under new powers handed to the government agency, AUSTRAC, amid concerns they're being used for money laundering and terror financing.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Questioning the Coalition's plans to tackle crime
item.description:
The Coalition has been making a lot of noise about youth crime, particularly in Victoria, so what solutions is it offering up? Sally Sara interviews the new shadow Attorney General Andrew Wallace.

Then we hear from Pauline Hanson as One Nation surges in the polls. 

And we'll finish in Madagascar, where the military says it's in control of the country, after the nation's president was impeached while in hiding.

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: Key Liberal wants 'apology tour' to end
item.description:
The Liberal Party needs to end its post-election "apology tour" and "mass therapy session", according to one of its most senior frontbenchers.

In a wide-ranging speech last night, Shadow Finance Minister James Paterson warned that his party could face destruction if it adopts a Nigel Farage-style populist agenda. But Mr Paterson also rejected suggestions the Liberals should position themselves as free market teals. 

Then, an Arab-Israeli member of the Knesset worries that far-right politicians will justify returning to war in Gaza based on Hamas delays in returning Israeli hostage bodies. We hear from Aida Touma-Sliman. 

Also today, we look at Oral history. Its considered the world's oldest form of sharing knowledge and culture, and in Australia, Aboriginal people have been sharing stories this way for thousands of years.

Earlier this week, former prime minister Tony Abbott launched a new book tracing the history of Australia and questioned the reliability of oral history.

In response, Yorta Yorta man and chair of the First Nations Foundation, Ian Hamm, says "substance and an accurate record of events" are at the centre of oral history.

And in the wake of the algal bloom outbreak in South Australian waters, the state and federal governments are contributing more than $100 million to spruik this message.  

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.

item.title: Breakfast Wrap: When will the Gaza humanitarian situation improve?
item.description:
There's jubilation in Israel over the release of all the remaining living hostages, and in Palestine, over the return of detainees from Israeli detention.

But when will the humanitarian situation in Gaza begin to improve?

We'll hear from UNICEF and head to Israel to hear from a human rights group monitoring the release of both groups. 

Then, treasurer Jim Chalmers has announced significant changes to the government's superannuation tax policy reforms. You'll find out what he has to say. 

Recap the morning's news, politics and global affairs with the Breakfast Wrap.
